Literature Review:
Asymmetric stem cell division and germline immortality have been extensively studied in various organisms, including yeast, mice, and humans. The germline's ability to maintain its immortality has been a subject of interest for scientists, as it has enabled the continuation of multicellular life for the last 1.5 billion years. In this review, we will examine the mechanisms of germline immortality and how asymmetric cell division contributes to the resetting of cellular age. We will draw a parallel between yeast and multicellular organisms to understand the underlying mechanisms of germline immortality.

Germline immortality is a complex process that involves the maintenance of stem cell populations and the regulation of cellular aging. Asymmetric cell division, a process in which one daughter cell receives more resources than the other, has been shown to play a crucial role in the germline's ability to maintain its immortality. In yeast, asymmetric cell division has been shown to contribute to the resetting of cellular age by allowing the germline to maintain its stem cell populations (1).

In multicellular organisms, asymmetric cell division has been shown to be essential for the maintenance of stem cell populations in the germline. For example, in mice, asymmetric cell division has been shown to contribute to the maintenance of spermatogonial stem cells (2). Similarly, in humans, asymmetric cell division has been shown to be essential for the maintenance of spermatogonial stem cells (3).

One of the key mechanisms by which asymmetric cell division contributes to germline immortality is through the regulation of ribosomal DNA. Ribosomal DNA is essential for the synthesis of ribosomes, which are necessary for protein synthesis. In yeast, the regulation of ribosomal DNA has been shown to be critical for the maintenance of stem cell populations (4). Similarly, in multicellular organisms, the regulation of ribosomal DNA has been shown to be essential for the maintenance of stem cell populations in the germline (5).

In addition to asymmetric cell division and the regulation of ribosomal DNA, other mechanisms have been shown to contribute to germline immortality. For example, the expression of specific genes has been shown to be essential for the maintenance of stem cell populations in the germline (6). Similarly, the regulation of telomere length has been shown to be critical for the maintenance of stem cell populations in the germline (7).

In conclusion, asymmetric stem cell division and germline immortality are complex processes that involve the maintenance of stem cell populations and the regulation of cellular aging. The mechanisms underlying germline immortality are multifaceted and involve the regulation of asymmetric cell division, ribosomal DNA, gene expression, and telomere length. Drawing a parallel between yeast and multicellular organisms has provided valuable insights into the underlying mechanisms of germline immortality.
